CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (non-exhaustion);Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of Art. 6-1 and P1-1;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in the town of GPE , in LOC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sued ORG of ORG and PERSON in tort . A stamp on his statement of claims shows that ORG of GPE received the statement of claim on DATE . According to the Government , ORG received the statement of claim on CARDINAL DATE and listed the first hearing for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned due to the judge 's leave . The following hearing on DATE did not take place because of the defendants ' absence .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered an expert study and stayed the proceedings . The experts ' report was received by ORG in DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant 's representative amended the claims and asked ORG to resume the proceedings and to question witnesses . The applicant then again amended the claims in DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG resumed the proceedings and summoned witnesses .
CARDINAL . DATE and DATE ORG listed CARDINAL hearings , of which CARDINAL were adjourned because the defendants defaulted and CARDINAL were postponed because none of the parties attended .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adjourned the proceedings because the applicant appeared to have lost interest in the case . The applicant 's representative objected to that decision , indicating that neither he nor the applicant had been duly apprised of the hearing dates .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG quashed the decision of DATE and resumed the proceedings , having found no evidence that the applicant and/or his representative had been duly notified of the hearings .
CARDINAL . Upon the applicant 's request , on DATE ORG adjourned the proceedings because a similar claim was pending before another court . The proceedings were resumed on DATE .
CARDINAL . DATE and DATE CARDINAL hearings were adjourned because the parties did not attend .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG suspended the proceedings by reason of the applicant 's repeated failure to appear . The proceedings were then resumed on DATE once it had been discovered that the applicant and his representative had not been duly summoned to the hearings .

CARDINAL . Of the QUANTITY hearings listed between DATE and DATE , CARDINAL hearings were adjourned due to PERSON absence , CARDINAL hearings due to the parties ' absence , CARDINAL upon the applicant 's representative 's request and CARDINAL because the presiding judge was on leave .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's claim . On DATE the Rostov ORG quashed the judgment of DATE and remitted the matter for a new consideration by ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG listed the first hearing for DATE . Of the CARDINAL hearings fixed DATE and DATE , CARDINAL were adjourned because the defendants defaulted and CARDINAL was postponed upon the defendants ' request .
CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the applicant 's request , ORG ordered an expert study and stayed the proceedings .
CARDINAL . The proceedings were later resumed and on DATE ORG partly allowed the applicant 's action . The judgment of DATE was upheld on appeal by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant transported goods in his car from GPE to GPE and crossed the border without declaring the goods at the NORP customs . On DATE policemen of the Rostov Regional police department stopped the applicant and seized his car due to a violation of customs regulations . On DATE the ORG town customs issued a confiscation order in respect of the car and organised its sale in DATE through a private company .

CARDINAL . The applicant brought an application to a court seeking invalidation of the confiscation order of DATE . NORP On DATE the ORG quashed the confiscation order of CARDINAL DATE and held that the ORG town customs should return the car to the applicant . The judgment did not become final as the town customs appealed against it .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG issued a charging order over the car with a view to preventing it from being sold , holding that the car should be seized and returned to the applicant . The charging order was binding , enforceable and addressed to any current holder of the applicant 's car .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's representative handed over the charging order of DATE to the bailiffs . The covering letter of CARDINAL DATE listed a writ of execution of DATE as an enclosure and bore a stamp of the NORP Town bailiffs ' service .
CARDINAL . In DATE the bailiffs established that the private company had sold the car to Mr S. in DATE . However , they did not impound the car .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Rostov ORG quashed the judgment of CARDINAL DATE and remitted the matter concerning the confiscation order of DATE for a fresh examination . The charging order of CARDINAL DATE remained unaffected .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant successfully amended his claims . He dropped his claims against the ORG town customs and sought repossession of his car from Mr S.
CARDINAL . In DATE a bailiff asked PERSON about the location of the car . A written statement by PERSON read as follows :

“ I use [ the car ] for transportation of goods from GPE to GPE . It is kept at my house in the town of GPE , the address : GPE street , CARDINAL , in the territory of ORG “ Ikar ” . The car is now in GPE but it will come back around DATE ... ”
CARDINAL . In DATE , DATE the bailiffs ordered that PERSON produce the car to the ORG town bailiffs ' office . Mr S. did not respond .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG adjourned the enforcement proceedings , upon Mr S. 's request . That decision was quashed by ORG on DATE . The matter was remitted for a fresh examination to ORG and the enforcement was resumed .
CARDINAL . In DATE Mr S. asked the local road police department to cancel the car registration on the ground that it would be sold to a purchaser in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE Mr S. informed the bailiffs that the car had been sold . The bailiffs , in their turn , told the applicant that the car had been sold and that Mr S. had refused to inform them who had bought the car . They asked whether the applicant would be willing to pay for the search of the car . The applicant agreed to bear the costs .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG issued a judgment by which Mr S. should return the car to the applicant . On DATE a writ of execution was issued . The applicant submitted it to the bailiffs and asked them to calculate an approximate cost of the search . On DATE enforcement proceedings were instituted , but the applicant 's request for the calculation remained unanswered .
CARDINAL . In DATE Mr S. bought a new car and asked the road police department to have it registered . A copy of the request indicated PERSON home address .
CARDINAL . On DATE the enforcement proceedings related to the judgment of DATE were discontinued because the bailiffs could not , allegedly , find Mr S. 's residence or the vehicle .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ordered the bailiffs to impound CARDINAL cars belonging to Mr S. with a view to enforcing the judgment of DATE . According to the Government , the bailiffs began searching for the cars on DATE , but never completed it because the applicant had refused to advance payment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG , upon the applicant 's request , ordered that Mr S. pay the applicant MONEY ( RUR ) in lieu of the car . The judgment became final on DATE and on DATE enforcement proceedings were instituted .
CARDINAL . In DATE PERSON applied for renewal of his passport . His passport application listed his unchanged place of residence . On DATE Mr S. received the passport .

CARDINAL . In DATE the bailiffs , in the enforcement proceedings related to the judgment of CARDINAL DATE , issued a decision stating that PERSON did not have any property and that the place of his residence was unknown .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant received a calculation of the advance payments for the search of PERSON property . He was to advance RUR CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( approximately EUR CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant asked a prosecutor 's office to institute criminal proceedings against Mr S. for his failure to abide by an enforceable judicial decision . In DATE , DATE and DATE an investigator questioned Mr PERSON proceedings were not instituted . The prosecutor 's documents listed the same place of Mr S. 's residence as in DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiffs initiated the search of PERSON property without any advance payment by the applicant . It appears that the enforcement proceedings are still pending .
CARDINAL . On several occasions the applicant complained to the courts about the bailiffs ' failure to enforce the charging order of DATE and the judgments of DATE and CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed CARDINAL complaint , finding that the bailiffs had acted properly , that they had known that Mr S. had purchased the car but had no reason to doubt that Mr S. had not been willing to return it . The bailiffs could not be held liable for the sale of the car by Mr S.

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed another complaint , holding that the decision of DATE ( by which the enforcement proceedings in respect of the judgment of DATE had been discontinued ) had been lawful because it had been impossible to locate Mr S. or his property . Although on DATE the applicant had agreed to pay for the search of PERSON property , the costs had not yet been calculated . The judgment of CARDINAL DATE was upheld on appeal on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed the applicant 's complaint about the bailiffs ' failure to enforce the judgments and to provide him with the calculation of the costs for the search of Mr S. 's property . The court held :

“ From the contents of the applicant 's complaint about the acts ( failures to act ) of the bailiffs ... it does not appear what rights or lawful interests have been violated and whether any damage has been caused , the complaint is unsubstantiated and may not be granted . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the NORP federal law “ on enforcement proceedings ” ( Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ) provides for certain measures which the bailiffs may take when private persons or public officials fail to comply with lawful orders , provide false information about a debtor 's income and financial status , do not inform a bailiff about the debtor 's dismissal from work , a change of the debtor 's places of work or residence or when they do not respond to the bailiff 's summonses . These measures include a fine of CARDINAL minimum wages , escorting a defaulting party by force to a place where enforcement actions are performed and institution of criminal proceedings .
